awd_titl_txt: Population-specific patterns of heritability and integration in the human dentition
awd_abstract_narration:
Teeth are an extraordinary resource for paleoanthropologists and archaeologists. They preserve well in the fossil and archaeological records, and contain a great deal of information about diet, environment, growth and development, and relatedness among populations or species.  However, the underlying biological processes influencing diversity in tooth form have yet to be fully established. This project uses dental cast samples and family genealogies from diverse bioregional samples to better understand the factors that influence the expression of shape characteristics on an individual tooth, among teeth within an individual's dentition, and among human populations. The findings from this project will advance knowledge about how tooth formation is shaped by genes, development, and childhood environment. The investigators will create an archive of high resolution 3D tooth scans and anonymized genealogies that will be hosted online and made freely available to a global network of scholars. This archive will enhance the research and educational infrastructure for not only biologists and anthropologists, but also clinical dentists, orthodontists, and forensic odontologists who conduct primary research in applied fields. Additionally, the work supports undergraduate and graduate student training at Arizona State University, a diverse and inclusive environment with a high representation of Hispanic and Native American students.

This research uses measurements and observations on the crests, cusps, and furrows that characterize mammalian tooth crowns. Despite their use by numerous scholars across diverse fields, we still do not fully understand how the process of tooth formation is genetically controlled and how different teeth within the dentition are integrated with respect to developmental processes that include both genetic and non-genetic factors. In this project, 150-250 observations will be collected from each of approximately 3,000 individuals from five samples representing distinct modern human populations. Quantitative genetic analyses will be used to estimate the relative contribution of genes and environment in determining variation in tooth size and shape (heritability). Estimates of genetic correlation (pleiotropy) among dimensions and shape variables will define how an organism forms similar tissues (teeth) at different times (in-utero versus early childhood) under the same developmental program and with input from overlapping genetic factors. These estimates will be compared across the five populations to assess whether a general human pattern is evident, and if not, to determine what factors explain disparities between populations. Results will yield insights into how researchers can use dental data as a genetic proxy measure, with an emphasis on the use of teeth from archaeological or forensic contexts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Teeth are used in many fields of study as an indicator of relatedness. For example, teeth are often used to identify new species in the fossil record and to determine their evolutionary relationships. Teeth are also essential for identifying deceased individuals in forensic contexts, often through matching the dental profiles of victims to clinical images or radiographs. Teeth are also used in archaeological studies to examine interactions between ancient populations and, in some cases, to identify nuclear families buried within the same cemetery.

Teeth are especially critical to these efforts when DNA is not available—often in cases of poor preservation, insufficient funding for testing, or lack of permission to extract samples. In these instances, researchers utilize the size and shape of individuals’ teeth to reconstruct relationships. The reason for this is because: a) teeth are extremely durable, b) their size and shape are determined early in development, and c) many of their features are thought to be controlled by genes.

Despite their many uses in understanding relatedness, few studies have examined large samples of contemporary human teeth to verify point (c) above and to better understand how dental size and appearance is patterned with respect to relatedness of individuals. This is important, because we know that genes are not the only things determining tooth form. Instead, genes interact with different aspects of the environment, such as diet or health history, while they are forming.

This project addressed this need by examining the effects of genetic and environment on tooth form. Researchers collected data from human dental casts collected from populations for which family relationships were recorded. The researchers recorded information on tooth size (72 measurements) and minor anatomical variation (184 characters) observed on the crown surfaces. All dental casts were photographed and digitized using orthodontic scanners to create three-dimensional models.

Researchers used the anonymized dental and genealogical data to estimate heritability for individual tooth traits – this is the portion of tooth variation determined by genetic relatedness. They also estimated genetic correlations to examine which anatomical features are determined by the same sets of genes. The results (based on two of the study samples) indicate that genetic effects account for, on average, 50% of tooth size variation; the influence of genes was weaker for other crown traits. Results also suggest significant overlap in the genes controlling incisor, canine, and premolar size, as well as paired traits on the left and right sides of the dentition. Interestingly, genetic correlations are higher for corresponding traits on different teeth (for example, a particular cusp observed on neighboring molars) than for multiple traits observed on a single tooth crown. The research team also found that linear enamel hypoplasias (LEH)—grooves or defects visible on the tooth surface often associated with childhood experiences of physiological stress—are less influenced by genes than by shared environment or household. This suggest a familial (but not genetic) predisposition for both LEH and major health events like malnutrition or illness.

These findings impact the ways in which bioarchaeologists study the past in several ways. First, they provide empirical support for common assumptions about the nature of the dentition: a) teeth are strongly influences by genes, especially tooth size, b) the same genes are recruited throughout development to generate similar cusps, fissures, and crests on neighboring teeth but this is not always the case for different features on the same tooth, c) left/right side symmetry is, in part, maintained by overlapping genetic effects, and d) shared environment is more influential than shared biology in the formation of enamel defects associated with childhood stress. This information can guide the ways in which researchers collect, analyze, and interpret their dental datasets. Analyses are still ongoing in some of the project samples, but once completed, the research team will verify whether these patterns are upheld across several populations. Ultimately, this project will provide comprehensive insight into how and why human teeth vary.

To date, results of this work have yielded/contributed to four peer-reviewed quantitative genetic publications, an applied simulation study, and a foundational literature review. Project outcomes also include five presentations at national and international conferences, as well as three public outreach lectures for the local community and clinical continuing education groups. The project has helped to train several graduate students, dozens of undergraduate students, and three postdoctoral researchers who have accepted full-time jobs in related fields. The images and scans yielded by this project have been the focus of two undergraduate honors projects, a MA thesis, and several graduate research projects. Importantly, these resources are freely available through the dentalphenomics.org archives, which is expanding to accommodate newly-scanned samples. Educators and researchers can view the images and anonymized pedigrees online, with special use requests reviewed by original sample curators.
